div1.p: Carter, Jr., comments on various topics including the California plague, the Surgeon General appointment, and family members.

div1.head: Letter from Henry Rose Carter, Jr., to Henry Rose Carter, November 13, 1924
div1.p:
We are having quite a drought in this section, as it has
not rained since the latter part of August. By this time I suppose Laura
has started on her rest and you are collecting data from the library for
the other section of “THE BOOK”. I hope that you are having a nice fall in
Washington for as a rule the fall is the pleasentest part of the year in
Maryland, the District and Virginia. Its fairly quite here from a pro-
fessional point of view but I have had a certain number of consultations
since I last wrote you. I trust that my brother Edward has continured
to improve under the treatment. In looking over the programme of the
Southern Medical Association it appears to me that the Malarial Section is
by far the best that they have on their programme as the section on in-
ternal medicine is not preticularly interesting. The demonstration of
the test fimunity to scarlet fever by the Dicks of Chicago should be of
real intrest. From what the papers write they must have a very
difficult problem in LoS Angeles with the Plegue situation, I mean that
its in the pneumonic form. But the Service has been expecting it to appear
again in California and so it not a surprise. What officer was assigned to
this duty?

I put in my application for the Reserve Corps and if commisioned will be
a Lt. Colonel.

What is going to make the real difference to the United States is the boys
in college and high schools who belong to the R.O.T.C.: for they will be
trained from youth and make better officers than the older men dispite our
war experance.

I was just wondering how old General Ireland was and if he will be retired
before he is reappointed. If so I judge Noble will again come out as a
candidate but his chances with a Republican President are not as good as
a Demecratic one.

I certainly am glad that the Service reappointed Dr Cumming and that he
has now a sufficient peroid of time, i.e. two tearms, in which to do
real constructive work. Do you ever see anything of Mr. and Mrs Tharpe
since they have moved to Washington? I hope you secro -iliac condition
is giving you less trouble than when you last wrote.

Did Laura get over to Baltimoe and see Tom Brown before she stated to take
her rest as she had planned?

I know what a happiness it is for you and Aunt Mary to be togeather again
for she certainly is one of the most wonderful poeple I have ever had the
good fortune to meet.

This can only be a note but I was thinking of you and wanted to write
and ask about you Laura and Aunt Mary.
All you meet here ask to be remembered each time I write.
With love to you and Aunt Mary and Laura

closer.salute: I am always your devoted son
closer.seg:
P. S. Please remember me to such friends
as you may see in Washington and
Especially to Mrs Gorgas
H R C
